data.meta_description: “Kilroy Was Here”Want a cultural reference that Steve and Bucky would, 100% be familiar with? Kilroy is it — A long-nosed, bald figure, peeking over a wall accompanied by the words “Kilroy was...
data.text:
Indexed Recipe Wednesday Masterpost

This is an indexed Masterpost of all the recipes that appear in the Recipe Wednesday posts from @steve-rogers-new-york . Unlike the previous Recipe Wednesday masterlist, this version is ordered by the recipes themselves. Each recipes is grouped and sorted based on food type, then linked to the post they appear in.

The below are the real period recipes that have appeared in the weekly Recipe Wednesday posts, each taken from the Brooklyn Daily Eagle — a local newspaper that would have been accessible to Steve, his mother, and Bucky during their time in Brooklyn. The recipes range in content from dinner meals, snack, condiments, and desserts — and feature an image of the recipe as it appeared in the newspaper, a link to the digitised copy of the paper, and transcriptions of the recipes.

Recipe Wednesday Masterpost!

Chocolate CakesThis is a Masterpost of all the Recipe Wednesday posts from @steve-rogers-new-york . Also see the indexed masterlist that lists the recipes by type.

The below are weekly posts featuring real period recipes, taken from the Brooklyn Daily Eagle — a local newspaper that would have been accessible to Steve, his mother, and Bucky during their time in Brooklyn. The recipes range in content from dinner meals, snack, condiments, and desserts — and feature an image of the recipe as it appeared in the newspaper, a link to the digitised copy of the paper, and transcriptions of the recipes.

Words: Military and War Related

This is a list of words and terms relating to the military or war, divided into those Steve would have potentially have known, and those that came into use after he went into the ice. The majority of these will be familiar to modern readers. Included are each word’s earliest recorded usage in a military context. Some words are repeated from the earlier posted generalised list. Many of these terms had earlier usages, but the dates provided relate to their usage within a military context, either during either Steve’s era, or after.

The first list features words and terms used during Steve’s era, either by U.S. military personnel or in civilian contexts following WWI. It appears the use of military terms was quick-spreading among soldiers and other personnel, as such, it is likely the words in this list were known to Steve.

The second list of words and terms are those introduced within a military context after Steve went into the ice in 1945. The terms on this list are just as important as those introduced during Steve’s time in the 1920-1940s —it’s the terms in this list that will be new to Steve when he wakes in the 21st century. The terms on this lists would a) Be new and unfamiliar to Steve when he wakes up, and b) Should not be used by Steve (in fanfiction) until he has realistically become more familiar with the changes in the english language and military terminology while he was sleeping. Imagine you’re learning a new language, you don’t pick up all the formal and colloquial vocabulary at once, it’s generally a gradual process — though with his near-eidetic memory, Steve could viably consume a dictionary or military handbook, but even then he would need time to get used to using the new words in everyday conversation.

Pre-1945

Ace: An outstanding pilot — Technically, one who has brought down 10 enemy planes (1917)

Ammo: Shortened form of ammunition (1917)

Artillery: Warlike munitions (late 14th century)

Artillery barrage: A line or barrier of exploding artillery shells, created by continuous and co-ordinated fire of a large number of guns (1917)

Blitzkrieg: High-speed, offence tactics used by the German army in the opening months of WWII (1939)

Blitz: Sudden, violent military attack, especially by air (1939)

Blitz: Slang for any sudden dash or movement in or out of a place (1940)

Bomb: To attack with bombs (1909)

Classified: Classified as secret for reasons of national security and forbidden to be disclosed except to specified persons (1944)

Commando: A member of a body of picked men trained originally as shock troops for repelling the threatened German invasion of England, later for carrying out raids on the Continent and elsewhere (1940)

Counteroffensive: A large-scale operation to halt an enemy’s offensive, while occupying defensive positions (1909)

Demilitarized zone: An area in which by agreement between nations, military powers or contending groups forbid military installations, activities to personal (1921)

Dog tag: A metal identification tag for military personnel, featuring the soldier’s name, service number, and other information (1918)

First world war: Hypothetical use indicating that the 1914-1918 conflict was not the “war to end all wars” (1914)

Flamethrower: Weapon that shoots a stream of burning liquid (1917)

Foo fighter: Term used by Allied aircraft pilots to describe mysterious aerial phenomena seen in the skies over Europe and the Pacific (1944)

Freedom-fighter: Someone who takes part in a resistance movement against the established political system of a country (1942)

FUBAR: U.S. military slang, acronym for “Fucked/Fouled Up Beyond All Recognition” (1944)

Genocide: The deliberate and systematic extermination of an ethnic or national group. The term was coins specifically in response to the Nazis’ slaughter of six million Jews (about two-thirds of European Jewry) in concentration camps during World War II (1944)

G.I.: Semi-official U.S. Army abbreviation for galvanised iron, used in inventories and supply records (1907)

G.I. can: German artillery shell (1918)

G.I.: Shortened form of G.I. can (1919)

G.I.: Government Issue, applied to anything having to do with the army (1918)

G.I.: Enlisted soldier (1939)

G.I. Joe: A Generic enlisted man (1935)

Great War: Reference to the Napoleonic Wars (1887)

Great War: Reference to the 1914-1918 war (1914)

Jeep: A small, sturdy four-wheel-drive US army vehicle, used chiefly for reconnaissance (1941)

Logistics: “Art of moving, quartering, and supplying troops” (1879)

Napalm: A flammable liquid used in warfare (1942)

No man’s land: The area between the trench lines (1908)

POW: Acronym for “prisoner of war,” not common until World War II (1919)

Radar: A system for detecting the presence of objects at a distance, to ascertaining their position or motion, by transmitting short radio waves and detecting or measuring their return after being reflected (1941)

Recon: Shortened form of reconnaissance (1918)

Refugee (1914)

Rocket: An engine that provides thrust by the ejection of burnt fuel (1919)

Roger: Used in radio communication to mean “Yes, I understand” (1941)

Scorched earth policy: Military policy in which houses, crops, factories and other resources of an area are destroyed so that an enemy cannot use them (1937)

Secret weapon: A weapon classified as secret (1936)

Shell Shock: A severe neurosis originating in trauma suffered under fire. The term in particularly associated with World War I, in which soldiers on the Western Front were subjected to a seemingly incessant barrage of shell-fire (1915)

Shrapnel: Fragments form exploded shell artillery (1940)

SNAFU: U.S. military slang, acronym for “Situation Normal: All Fucked/Fouled Up.” An expression conveying the acceptance of the disorder of war, and the ineptitude of their superiors (1941)

Terrorism: Attempted actions to achieve political goals through violence and intimidation (1798)

Terrorist: Someone who attempted to achieve political goals through violence and intimidation (1798)

Uncle Sam (1813)

United Nations: Originally, the Allied nations who united against the Axis powers in World War II (1942)

V sign: Originally applied to the letter V used as a written symbol of victory during World War II, or to the Morse Code representation of this, and subsequently to a two-fingered gesture representing V for victory. Made famous by the British prime minister Winston Churchill (1941)

Weapon of mass destruction: A weapon intended to cause widespread destruction and loss of life. Low profile usage until the 1990s (1937)

Whizbang: Allied soldier’s name for a type of German artillery shell, so-called for their characteristic sound (1915)

World war: Hypothetical future war involving the great nations of Europe (1909)

World war: Reference to the 1914-1918 war (1914)

World War 2: Hypothetical reference to a second war involving the great nations (1919)

World War II: Referring specifically to the 1939-1945 conflict (1939)

Post 1945

Affirmative action: Positive or corrective effort to prevent discrimination of minority groups — such as the disabled or disadvantaged, women, and other racial or ethnic groups — in regards to hiring, admission, retention, or promotion (1964)

Agent Orange: A chemical defoliant and herbicide used widely in Vietnam around base camps, and extensive or prolonged exposure to which caused numerous serious medical conditions (1965)

Air-lift: Transportation of supplies or troops by air, especially during a state of emergency (1945)

APC: Armored Personnel Carrier (1952)

Asset: A resource available to an army force; a piece of military hardware (1977)

Asylum seeker: A person who seeks political asylum in another country (1959)

Atom bomb: A bomb whose explosive power derives from the fission of heavy atomic nuclei (1945)

Axis of evil: A polemical term applied in the US in the wake of the attack on the World Trade Center and other targets in 2001, to a group of stated identified as harbouring and promoting terrorism aimed at the West or as building up stocks of weapons intended to be used against the West (2001)

Ballistic: Rockets or missiles, that are guided while under propulsion, but fall freely during descent (1949)

Ballistic missile: A missile guided while under propulsion, but falls freely in descent — specifically one which attain extreme heights (1954)

Brain-washing: The systematic and often forcible elimination from a person’s mind of all established ideas, especially political ones, so that another set of ideas can take their place; this process regarded as the kind of coercive conversion practiced by certain totalitarian states on political dissidents (1950)

Clusterfuck: U.S. military slang, bungled or confused undertaking (1969)

Collateral damage: Destruction or injury beyond the intent or expectation of an aggressor, usually occurring in a civilian area surrounding a military target. The term is commonly used as a euphemism for ‘accidentally killing civilians’ (1975)

Count-down: The action of counting in reverse, from a given number to zero, usually in seconds, to mark the lapse of time before an explosion, the launch of a missile, etc (1953)

Disinformation: The dissemination of deliberately false information, especially when supplied by a government or its agent to a foreign power or to the media, with the intension of influencing the policies or opinions of those who receive it (1955)

Dustoff: Call-sign for emergency casualty evacuation from a combat zone (1963)

East: The states of eastern Europe during the Cold War; the communist powers; the Soviet bloc (1951)

Ethnic cleansing: The purging, by mass expulsion or killing, of one ethnic or religious group by another. Introduced by the inter-ethnic conflict in the former Yugoslavia (1991)

Fall-out: Radioactive refuse of a nuclear bomb explosion; also, the process of deposition of such refuse (1950)

Frag: U.S. military slang, shortened form of “fragmentation grenade” (1970)

Free world: The non-communist countries of the world (1955)

Geneva Conventions: Four treaties and three additional protocols that establish the standards of international law for the humanitarian treatment of war (1949)

Ground Zero: The part of the ground situated immediately under an exploding bomb, especially a nuclear one (1946)

Grunt: U.S. military slang, infantry soldier (1969)

Incoming: A warning cry of incoming shellfire (1968)

Nuclear winter: A period of extreme cold and devastation that has been conjectured to follow a nuclear war, caused by an atmospheric layer of smoke and dust particles shutting out the sun’s rays (1983)

Self-destruct: Detonating mechanism enabling a missile or other device to destroy itself under certain conditions (1966)

Sonic boom: The sudden loud noise heard when the shock wave from an aircraft travelling faster than sound reaches ears (1952)

Strategic: Of delivering, or being nuclear weapons intended to destroy an enemy’s capacity to make war. The contrast is usually with tactical (1957), denoting nuclear weapons intended for short-range use (1957)

Surgical: Designating swift and precise military attack, especially from the air (1965)

Tactical: Of delivering, or being nuclear weapons intended for short-range use (1957)

Terrorist: A member of a clandestine or expatriate organisation aiming to coerce an established government by acts of violence against it or its subjects (1947)

Third World War: A hypothetical war, subsequent to World War II, involving most of the world’s nations. The concept was in people’s minds before World War II ended, and remained there throughout the Cold War (1947)

United Nations Organisation: An international peace-seeking organisation of those nations involved in the Unite nations/Allied nations, and many others states. Founded by charter in 1945 (1945)

U.N.: Common abbreviation for the United Nations Organisation (1946)

U.N.O.: Acronym for the United Nations Organisation (1945)

West: The non-Communist states of the world in opposition to the Social bloc during the Cold War. More political than geographical (1946)

Related Posts: Words by Decade: General Pre-1900s-1910s and Words by Decade: General 1920-1945 and Words by Decade: General Mid to Late 1940s and Words by Decade: General 1950s-1960s and Words by Decade: General 1970s-2000s

Steve Rogers’ NY Masterpost!

[ Support Steve Rogers’ New York on Patreon! ]

I’ll be keeping this post updated.

Steve Rogers’ New York is a period historical blog centred around the ever-lovable and admirable Steven Grant Rogers, better known as Captain America! It looks at a range of elements from 1920s - Mid 1940s New York and American culture as they would relate to, would have shaped, Steve and his world view.
